nodes.bodyText: It would be better to use a utility that exists in Amplify, directly. This utility is from a dependency which may/may not be removed in the future (when we do the auth category), and also it is marked .internal. (meaning, "don't consume this from another library.")

A problem here is that you have a way to register the callbacks, but no way to unregister the callbacks.
Someday, Amplify will probably have some kind of teardown() method. And it would call through and we'd want to do:
application.unregisterActivityLifecycleCallbacks(this);

So, either:

Just stash a reference to the Application into an instance variable, and provide two new methods, startTracking(), and stopTracking(). These methods would call application.registerActivityLifecycleCallbacks(this) and application.unregisterActivityLifecycleCallbacks(this).
Don't bother passing an Application at all. Just document in the class Javadoc for ApplicationLifecycleHelper that you intend for instances of this class to registered elsewhere, by someone else making calls to registerActivityLifecycleCallbacks(Application.ActivityLifecycleCallbacks) and unregisterActivityLifecycleCallbacks(Application.ActivityLifecycleCallbacks).

Same issue here, there's no  way to do application.unregisterReceiver(...), if you do this right in the constructor. So, it probably shouldn't happen in the constructor, but rather in the startTracking() / stopTracking() methods I propose above.

ActivityBase and AppCompatActivity have existing solutions to track/obtain the current lifecycle. Checkout the AndroidX Lifecycle Components, with which V7 App Compat Activity is integrated.
However, I can see an advantage to having something that works with every single Activity, ever. And for that, I guess you might need to have your own tracker.
A good name for this class might be ApplicationForegroundTracker, instead of ApplicationLifecycleHelper.
Anyway, even if you implement your own tracker, you can still use as much of AndroidX Lifecycle here as possible. Instead of using strings, you should use enums, which provide a bounded set of possible states the map value can be in. And, as it turns out, that enum is already defined by AndroidX Lifecycle --
So this map would (probably) become:
private Map<Activity, Lifecycle.State> activityStates = new WeakHashMap<>();

(Ref: LifecycleState)
I have updated to use LifecycleState and updated the naming as well.

Made it a final class. We want to provide this feature automatically where session are recorded for every time app goes to back ground after it is brought to foreground. Enduser should not have to write any code for it. Will discuss offline

This method name is long to the point of being unreadable. Maybe just inline that method, here? Or, name it like checkForApplicationEnteredForeground()?  As a bonus, this would match your checkForApplicationBackground() method.

I have some more clean-ups lined up where I have this change, cleaning up comments and removing Screen off receiver because it turn out screen turn off also causes running activity to stop thus giving a onStop callback. This PR is WIP and there is no way to make it a Draft PR once its marked ready for review :/
In our call, we agreed that this can be removed.

For some of these, you have "app is in goreground" was a "when" step, but it is more like a "given."
For example, "Given that the app had already been opened, when the user hits the home button, then the session is stopped."
This will change your "then" logic slightly too, since I think you'll only want to verify stopSession(), in that case, not both startSession() and stopSession(), back to back.
Although, that InOrder is cool!! I'm surprised I've never seen it before. Nice find.
